text: What is DNS and How Does It Work?
When you visit a website like www.google.com, have you ever wondered how your browser magically knows where to go? You didn’t enter an IP address, yet you landed on the right page instantly.
That’s the magic of DNS.
Let’s explore how the internet figures out where to send you when you type a website name — and why DNS is one of the most critical systems on the web.
What is a DNS?
DNS stands for Domain Name System. It’s like the phonebook of the internet, translating human-friendly domain names (like hello.com) into computer-friendly IP addresses (like 142.250.64.78).
Computers use IP addresses to communicate with each other, but remembering numbers for every website would be impossible. That’s where DNS steps in.
Think of a domain name as someone’s name (e.g., 'Alice').
Think of an IP address as their home address (e.g., '123 Main Street').
You know Alice by name, but to send her a letter, you need her physical address.
Similarly, your browser uses DNS to find the IP address for a website name.
How Does DNS Work?
Here's what happens behind the scenes when you type a URL into your browser:
User enters a domain: You type www.example.com into your browser.
Browser checks local cache: If you’ve visited the site recently, your device may remember the IP address.
Query goes to a DNS resolver: If it's not in your cache, your device asks a DNS resolver (usually provided by your ISP or a public DNS like Google’s 8.8.8.8).
Resolver asks the root nameserver: It starts from the top. The root server points to the .com nameserver for your query.
TLD nameserver responds: The .com nameserver directs the resolver to the authoritative nameserver for example.com.
Authoritative nameserver replies with the IP: This server knows the exact IP address of www.example.com and sends it back.
Resolver sends IP to browser: Your browser can now connect to the actual server and load the website.
This whole process usually takes milliseconds.
Types of DNS Servers Involved
DNS Resolver: The first stop (usually managed by your ISP or Google Cloud DNS)
Root Nameserver: Knows where to find the Top-Level Domain (.com, .org, etc.)
TLD Nameserver: Knows where to find the specific domain (example.com)
Authoritative Server: Holds the actual DNS record for the domain
Caching
To speed things up, DNS records are cached at various levels (your device, the resolver, etc.). This means that if you visit a site again soon after, it can load even faster.
Why is DNS Important?
Without DNS, we’d have to remember IP addresses for every website. It’s a fundamental part of how the internet works.
DNS also plays a role in security. Features like DNSSEC help ensure that the responses you get are authentic and haven’t been tampered with.
